Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Reconstructing the Paleoenvironmental History of the Cuenca Oriental in Mexico's Trans-Mexican Volcanic Belt

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
This doctoral dissertation research project will examine possible linkages between climate change and prehistoric societies in the Cuenca Oriental, an area of interior drainage in the eastern Trans-Mexican Volcanic Belt. Drought has been invoked to explain the abandonment of many areas of Mesoamerica, but direct evidence is only available for a handful of sites, and non-climatic explanations often have been proposed. This doctoral dissertation research project will focus on development of a multi-proxy record of human occupation and Holocene climate change from Aljojuca and Alchichica, two maar lakes located near Cantona, an archaeological site in the northeastern part of the Cuenca Oriental. During the late Classic period, Cantona was one of the largest cities in the Americas, but the site was abandoned several hundred years later, possibly as a result of drought. The doctoral student will develop a record of Holocene climate change by analyzing the fossil pollen content, stable isotope composition, and sediment chemistry of sediment cores from Aljojuca and Alchichica. Pollen slides will be scanned for corn pollen as an index of agricultural activity in the area. These data will help reconstruct the timing of past changes in climate as well as the history of human settlement in the region. The Aljojuca core has already been recovered by an international scientific team from the National Autonomous University of Mexico and the GFZ German Research Center for Geosciences. Radiocarbon dating reveals that the core spans approximately 6,200 years.

This dissertation project will produce two new high-resolution, well-dated paleoenvironmental records from the eastern Trans-Mexican Volcanic Belt. These records will improve basic understanding of the timing of Holocene climate change in the region, especially the history of Mexico's summer rainfall regime. The project therefore will contribute to interdisciplinary debates in archaeology and geography about the role of climate change as a factor influencing human societies. The project will strengthen international collaborations among scientists in Mexico, Germany, and the U.S. Results will be disseminated through a variety of media for scholarly and public audiences, and they will be used in educational activities and lesson plans for undergraduate and K-12 students. As a Doctoral Dissertation Research Improvement award, this project will provide support to enable a promising student to establish an independent research career.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Our research explored the variability of the North American Monsoon (NAM) in Mexico's eastern Trans-Mexican Volcanic Belt (TMVB) during the late Holocene. Our paleoenvironmental reconstruction stretches from 6,000 calendar years before present to the present day. We used stable isotopes and elemental geochemistry of lake sediments to reconstruct multi-decadal climate variability. Pollen and charcoal provided evidence of past vegetation and fire.Our results are the first to show a dry period spanning several centuries, centered at approximately 1100 calendar years before present, in this part of eastern Mexico. By comparing our climate reconstructions to pollen results and the regional archaeological record, we elucidated linkages between climate, terrestrial ecosystems, and human cultural developments. 

Our results provide detailed information about the environmental history of a previously understudied region of the world. They also shed light on linkages between climate and past human cultures in a region of the world that was densely populated in pre-Columbian times. Understanding these linkages can provide important lessons on the factors that promote resilience or vulnerability to environmental change. These in turn can be applied to modern attempts to address anthropogenic climate change. We were able to show that human responses to climate change at the site of Cantona, a large site in the eastern TMVB, depended strongly on the broader sociopolitical context of the site. This highlights the importance of social and political factors in mediating responses to environmental change. Our results were published in several high-impact journals, including the Proceedings of the National Academies of Sciences. 

This project promoted awareness about the importance of climate change in past human societies. Efforts were also made to increase the visibility and participation of underrepresented groups in science. The co-PI actively participated in outreach events by the University of California, Berkeley Museum of Paleontology to promote women in science, and the project involved the training of two female undergraduate research assistants, who are now employed at scientific agencies. The project was a collaboration between scientists in Mexico, the United States, and Germany, and consequently strengthened partnerships with international research institutions.
